 First of all, let me preface with saying I am pro-choice. The baby isn't more or less precious. Anymore than my kid isn't more or less precious than the next person's.
 
 The difference is where you feel you can demand accountability. I think pro-life people who accept an exception in the case of incest and rape don't view the child as less precious, they simply don't feel the mother has the same accountability as she did not consent to the pregnancy. (Granted, there are misogynistic lifers those who want to hold women as slaves to any and all pregnancies that come along...)
 
 I really don't think the big pro-life vs pro-choice argument is about where life begins or whether or not life is precious. It's more a debate over 1 - whether the rights of mother or the child take precedence, 2 - how much accountability can we hold a pregnanct woman to.
 
 It's like me and my governer, Tim Pawlenty. We completely disagree on how much accountability government/citizens owe the school system.

 Is coercion synonymous with persuasion? I thought coercion included either violence or direct- or underlying threats of violence... But english is not my first language so I could very well be wrong...

You could be right here is what i found under coercion.
 
 COERCION - Criminal Law, Contracts. Constraint; compulsion; force. It is positive or presumed.
 
 Positive or direct coercion takes place when a man is by physical force compelled to do an act contrary to his will; for example, when a man falls into the hands of the enemies of his country and they compel him, by a just fear of death, to fight against it.
 
 It is presumed where a person is legally under subjection to another and is induced in consequence of such subjection to do an act contrary to his will. A married woman, for example, is legally under the subjection of her husband, and if in his company she commit a crime or offence, (except the offence of keeping a bawdy-house, in which case she is considered by the law as a principal), she is presumed to act under this coercion.
 
 As will is necessary to the commission of a crime or the making of a contract, a person coerced into either has no will on the subject and is not responsible.

 I believe that what he said was, hypothetically, if a woman was so distraught that she was about to commit suicide after being raped and becoming pregnant, he saw abortion as the lesser of two evils since her suicide would kill both of them. It doesn't negate his belief in the value of life, in this instance, it's a pragmatic numbers game approach. It doesn't mean that the fetus is less valuable, only that the combination of both the mother and fetus' death, via the mother's suicide, would be worse.
 This is a very logical position, IMO. You save one life to prevent the death of two. I don't see the twisted logic. emoticon_confused 
 
 Did I explain your position adaquetely, VOR?

It's a good summary of Voice of Reason's position, and the pro-life position as a whole. 
 
 Amusingly it's the same form of argument that pro-choice people use to justify allowing a mother to choose to have an abortion. Abortions are horrible, as we pro-choicers agree with the pro-lifers. And we agree that there are situations in which the mother must be supported at the great expense of the child, situations where doing otherwise would be worse. 
 
 I think it's easy to agree that the best situation is both the mother and child surviving. The next best situation is only the mother surviving. The third best situation is only the child surviving. The fourth best situation is neither the mother nor the child surviving. The fourth best is naturally the worst situation, with the third best being the second worst, and so on. 
 
 I suggest that it is obvious and agreed upon that the second worst (third best) situation is permissable only when a woman consents to giving her life for the sake of the child's life, a heroic action.
 
 Likewise I suggest that it is obvious and agreed upon that where a woman can and will choose to carry the child to term, the best situation, is prefered by all. 
 
 The argument seems to start when you try to define the second best (third worst) situation in terms of when it should occur rather than in terms of who makes the choice. Pro-lifers argue that only saving a mother's life itself is worth the child's life. Pro-choicers argue that a mother has interests beyond the prolongation of her life which no one else's interests (including the child's right to life) trump. 
 
 When the question of saving the life of a suicidal rape victim, through an abortion of her unwanted child, is agreed upon to avert the worst case scenario, then we are dealing with pragmatic issues of better-worse rather than clear-cut issues of right/wrong. 
 
 The pro-choice position depends on that pragmatic stance though, because it needs to show that it is better for a woman's right to choice trumps the child's right to life, in order to demonstrate the preferability of the pro-choice position. 
 
 In addressing this question the pro-life position admits that, although all life is equally sacred, there are times when we must be pragmatic and do what must be done to prevent worse from happening.
 
 This is why Duo accuses the pro-life position of "twisted logic" because he assumes that it follows from couching the question in such pragmatic terms that the answer must automatically be a pro-choice answer (which isn't true because the pro-life position is starting from a different set of values and therefore must necessarily arrive at a different answer consistent with pro-life principles).

Course isn't that saying the entire debate is meaningless as everyone is using different values, hence there is nothing wrong with abortions unless you try to stop them? However if the woman can get away with it then its just the same anyway.
 
 Onion reader eh?

Course isn't that saying the entire debate is meaningless as everyone is using different values, hence there is nothing wrong with abortions unless you try to stop them? However if the woman can get away with it then its just the same anyway.
No, not at all. It's pointing out that the debate is quite meaningful to both sides and that the issue is objectively decideable. Duo's attempt to frame pro-lifers as using a "twisted logic" fails because pro-choicers reason in the same way: abortion is bad and some x is worse. It cuts both ways though, because pro-choice is essentially an extension of the pragmatic position.

 An absolute moral code, with respect to abortion, would be easily codified. The ONLY reason that we have this discussion is because the SCOTUS removed the state's right to establish abortion legislation based on the citizens' moral codes. 
 

 [edit] Just curious, what if it was for the life of another, but not the mother? Say the husband would commit suicide?

 
 Too bad. From a purely pragmatic stance, you're taking a life to save a life, so there is a net loss of 1 life. With the mother, there's the possibility of a net loss of two lives. Apples and oranges, IMO.

A law regarding abortion could be made, and has been, but an absolute moral code could not. It would just be the relative one that the legislators have enforced. 
 
 I still think the suicide option just isn't workable on a practical level, might seem like a reasonable position but to try to make it law and then enforce it is going to run into a mass of problems, especially if you don't have the full support of the populance and the psychiatrists

If you live alone its even worse as you now have a baby and no job.

 you are wrong:
 
 http://www.bizhelp24.com/business_law/maternity-leave.shtml
 
 Employee Maternity Leave
 
 (and Paternity Leave)
 
 
 
 A pregnant employee is entitled to 26 weeks 'ordinary' maternity leave. There is no requirement for the employee to have served a specific amount of time to qualify for leave.

 VOR's link was to the UK law. It's much more generous than the US. In the US, it's unpaid leave.

Fair enough then - I can see the idea of having to support a child and yourself without being able to earn any money as a bad thing. Unless you were in a position where you were ready to have a child (and had saved up enough for it), in a lot of situations its a far harder choice than VoR makes out. 
 
 Sure its not going to apply to every situation, but for a single expectant mother in a lowing paying job, having to work extra hours and possibly a second job whilst pregant to be able to feed you and your child over the maternity leave is going to make you consider holding off starting a family to a more appropiate time.

VOR's link was to the UK law. It's much more generous than the US. In the US, it's unpaid leave.

 
 Here is a link pertaining to the U.S.
 
 http://www.itssimple.biz/biz_tools/text/P05_4402.html
 
 f you have 15 or more employees, you are subject to a federal law that protects pregnant women. The federal Pregnancy Discrimination Act, which is part of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, provides that women affected by pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions must be treated the same as other applicants and employees on the basis of their ability or inability to work. The law protects women against being fired, being refused a job, or being denied a promotion merely because they are pregnant. In addition, a woman usually may not be forced to go on leave as long as she is able to work.
 
 Pregnant women are to be treated in the same manner as other persons with temporary disabilities for purposes of leave as well as participation in benefit plans and health and disability insurance. Further, if other employees who take disability leave are entitled to get their jobs back when they are able to work again, so are women who are unable to work because of pregnancy.
